science","slug":"materials-science","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/39378"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=39378"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=39378"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=39378"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=39378"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":9866,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/nanotechnology\/","name":"nanotechnology","slug":"nanotechnology","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/9866"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=9866"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=9866"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=9866"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=9866"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":173,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/science\/","name":"science","slug":"science","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/173"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=173"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=173"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=173"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=173"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":4621,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startup\/","name":"startup","slug":"startup","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4621"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4621"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":91720,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/transmission\/","name":"transmission","slug":"transmission","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/91720"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=91720"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=91720"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=91720"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=91720"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2124896,"date":"2021-03-15T05:00:52","date_gmt":"2021-03-15T12:00:52","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2124896"},"modified":"2021-03-14T20:02:15","modified_gmt":"2021-03-15T03:02:15","slug":"deepsee-ai-raises-22-6m-series-a-for-its-ai-centric-process-automation-platform","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/deepsee-ai-raises-22-6m-series-a-for-its-ai-centric-process-automation-platform\/","title":{"rendered":"DeepSee.ai raises $22.6M Series A for its AI-centric process automation platform"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/deepsee.ai\/\">DeepSee.ai<\/a>, a startup that helps enterprises use AI to automate line-of-business problems, today announced that it has raised a $22.6 million Series A funding round led by led by ForgePoint Capital. Previous investors AllegisCyber Capital and Signal Peak Ventures also participated in this round, which brings the Salt Lake City-based company&#8217;s total funding to date to $30.7 million.<\/p>\n<p>The company argues that it offers enterprises a different take on process automation. The industry buzzword these days is &#8216;robotic process automation,&#8217; but DeepSee.ai argues that what it does is different. I describe its system as &#8216;knowledge process automation&#8217; (KPA). The company itself defines this as a system that &#8220;mines unstructured data, operationalizes AI-powered insights, and automates results into real-time action for the enterprise.&#8221; But the company also argues that today&#8217;s bots focus on basic task automation that doesn&#8217;t offer the kind of deeper insights that sophisticated machine learning models can bring to the table. The company also stresses that it doesn&#8217;t aim to replace knowledge workers but help them leverage AI to turn the plethora of data that businesses now collect into actionable insights.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2124897\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2124897\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2124897\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"661\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png 1920w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png?resize=150,97 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png?resize=300,194 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png?resize=768,496 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png?resize=680,439 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png?resize=1536,991 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/DeepSee-Main-Screen-e1596554737105.png?resize=50,32 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2124897\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> DeepSee.ai<\/p><\/div><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;Executives are telling me they need business outcomes and not science projects,&#8221; writes DeepSee.ai CEO Steve Shillingford. &#8220;And today, the burgeoning frustration with most AI-centric deployments in large-scale enterprises is they look great in theory but largely fail in production. We think that\u2019s because right now the current \u2018AI approach\u2019 lacks a holistic business context relevance. It\u2019s unthinking, rigid, and without the contextual input of subject-matter experts on the ground. We founded DeepSee to bridge the gap between powerful technology and line-of-business, with adaptable solutions that empower our customers to operationalize AI-powered automation \u2013 delivering faster, better, and cheaper results for our users.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>To help businesses get started with the platform, DeepSee.ai offers <a href=\"https:\/\/deepsee.ai\/platform\/\">three core tools<\/a>. There&#8217;s <a href=\"https:\/\/deepsee.ai\/platform\/#assembler\">DeepSee Assembler<\/a>, which ingests unstructured data and gets it ready for labeling, model review and analysis. Then, <a href=\"https:\/\/deepsee.ai\/platform\/#atlas\">DeepSee Atlas<\/a> can use this data to train AI models that can understand a company&#8217;s business processes and help subject-matter experts define templates, rules and logic for automating a company&#8217;s internal processes. The third tool, <a href=\"https:\/\/deepsee.ai\/platform\/#advisor\">DeepSee Advisor<\/a>, meanwhile focuses on using text analysis to help companies better understand and evaluate their business processes.<\/p>\n<p>Currently, the company&#8217;s focus is on providing these tools for insurance companies, the public sector and capital markets. In the insurance space, use cases include fraud detection, claims prediction and processing, and using large amounts of unstructured data to identify patterns in agent audits, for example.<\/p>\n<p>That&#8217;s a relatively limited number of industries for a startup to operate in, but the company says it will use its new funding to accelerate product development and expand to new verticals.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Using KPA, line-of-business executives can bridge data science and enterprise outcomes, operationalize AI\/ML-powered automation at scale, and use predictive insights in real time to grow revenue, reduce cost, and mitigate risk,&#8221; said Sean Cunningham, Managing Director of ForgePoint Capital. &#8220;As a leading cybersecurity investor, ForgePoint sees the daily security challenges around insider threat, data visibility, and compliance. This investment in DeepSee accelerates the ability to reduce risk with business automation and delivers much-needed AI transparency required by customers for implementation.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"ms-editor-squiggler\" style=\"color: initial; font: initial; font-feature-settings: initial; font-kerning: initial; font-optical-sizing: initial; font-variation-settings: initial; forced-color-adjust: initial; text-orientation: initial; text-rendering: initial; -webkit-font-smoothing: initial; -webkit-locale: initial; -webkit-text-orientation: initial; -webkit-writing-mode: initial; writing-mode: initial; zoom: initial; place-content: initial; place-items: initial; place-self: initial; alignment-baseline: initial; animation: initial; appearance: initial; aspect-ratio: initial; backdrop-filter: initial; backface-visibility: initial; background: initial; background-blend-mode: initial; baseline-shift: initial; block-size: initial; border-block: initial; border: initial; border-radius: initial; border-collapse: initial; border-end-end-radius: initial; border-end-start-radius: initial; Capital","slug":"forgepoint-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576692522"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576692522"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576692522"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576692522"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576692522"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2124968,"date":"2021-03-15T04:59:18","date_gmt":"2021-03-15T11:59:18","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2124968"},"modified":"2021-03-15T05:01:07","modified_gmt":"2021-03-15T12:01:07","slug":"elevatebio-raises-525m-to-advance-its-cell-and-gene-therapy-technologies","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/elevatebio-raises-525m-to-advance-its-cell-and-gene-therapy-technologies\/","title":{"rendered":"ElevateBio raises $525M to advance its cell and gene therapy technologies"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">ElevateBio, one of the leading biotech companies focused on gene-based therapies has raised a massive $525 million Series C round of financing, more than doubling the company&#8217;s $193 million Series B funding which closed last year. This new funding comes from existing investor Matrix Capital Management, and also adds new investors SoftBank and Fidelity Management &amp; Research Company, and will be used to help the company expand its R&amp;D and manufacturing capabilities, as well as continue to spin out new companies and partnerships based on its research.<\/p>\n<p>Cambridge, Mass-based ElevateBio was founded to bridge the world of academic research and development of cell and gene therapies with that of commercialization and production-scale manufacturing. The startup identified a need for more efficient means of brining to market the ample, promising science that was being done in developing therapeutics that leverage cellular and genetic editing, particularly in treatment of severe and chronic illness. Its business model focuses on both developing and commercializing its own therapies, and also working through long-term partnerships with academic research institutions and other therapeutics biotech companies to bring their own technologies to market.<\/p>\n<p>To this end, ElevateBio is in the business of frequent spin-out company creation, with the new entities each focused on a specific therapeutic. The company has announced three such companies to date, including AlloVir (in partnership with Baylor College of Medicine), HighPassBio (a venture with gene-editing company Fred Hutchinson) and Life Edit Therapeutics (in partnership with AgBiome). There are additional spin-outs in the works, too, according to ElevateBio, but they are not being disclosed publicly yet.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"2qvXefebrX\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/30\/cell-and-gene-therapy-startup-elevatebio-raises-170-million\/\">Cell and gene therapy startup ElevateBio raises $170M<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Cell and gene therapy startup ElevateBio raises $170M&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/30\/cell-and-gene-therapy-startup-elevatebio-raises-170-million\/embed\/#?secret=2qvXefebrX\" data-secret=\"2qvXefebrX\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>As you might expect, ElevateBio seems to have benefited from the increased appetite for biotech investment stemming from the global pandemic and its impacts. ElevateBio&#8217;s AlloVir spin-out is actually working on a T cell therapy candidate for addressing COVID-19, which is potentially effective in eliminating cells infected with SARS-CoV-2 in a patient to slow the spread of the disease and reduce its severity.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier \u2018how-to\u2019 event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear first-hand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company-building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in \u2013 there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion. Use code \u201cTCARTICLE at checkout to get <a href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1?promo=tcarticle&amp;display=true\">20 percent off tickets right here<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>ElevateBio, one of the leading biotech companies focused on gene-based therapies has raised a massive $525 million Series C round of financing, more than doubling the company&#8217;s $193 million Series B funding which closed last year. This new funding comes from existing investor Matrix Capital Management, and also adds new investors SoftBank and Fidelity Management Sciences","slug":"roivant-sciences","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576598789"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576598789"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576598789"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576598789"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576598789"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":374837,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/softbank\/","name":"Softbank","slug":"softbank","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/374837"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=374837"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=374837"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=374837"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=374837"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2124845,"date":"2021-03-15T04:15:54","date_gmt":"2021-03-15T11:15:54","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2124845"},"modified":"2021-03-15T04:30:43","modified_gmt":"2021-03-15T11:30:43","slug":"wework-unbundles-its-products-in-an-attempt-to-make-itself-over-but-will-the-strategy-work","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/wework-unbundles-its-products-in-an-attempt-to-make-itself-over-but-will-the-strategy-work\/","title":{"rendered":"WeWork unbundles its products in an attempt to make itself over, but will the strategy work?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For years, there was a debate as to whether WeWork was a tech company or more of a real estate play. At first, most people viewed WeWork as a real estate startup disguised as a tech startup.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">And as it kept scooping up more and more property, the lines continued to blur. Then we all watched as the company\u2019s valuation plummeted and its IPO plans went up in smoke. Today, WeWork is rumored to be <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/wework-in-talks-to-combine-with-spac-or-raise-money-privately-11611857306?mod=djemalertNEWS\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">going public<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> via <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.spglobal.com\/marketintelligence\/en\/news-insights\/latest-news-headlines\/wework-could-strike-blank-check-company-merger-deal-in-1st-week-of-march-8211-wsj-62874558\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">a SPAC <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">at a $10 valuation, down significantly from <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">the $47 billion it was valued at after <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">raising $1 billion in its SoftBank-led Series H<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> round in January 2019.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Co-founder and then-CEO Adam Neumann notoriously <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/09\/24\/report-weworks-adam-neumann-to-step-down-as-ceo\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">stepped down<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> later that year amid allegations of a toxic combination of arrogance and poor management. WeWork has since been very publicly trying to redeem itself and turn around investor &#8212; and public &#8212; perception.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Chairman Marcelo Claure kicked off a strategic, five-year turnaround plan in earnest in February 2020. That same month, the beleaguered company named a real estate &#8212; not tech &#8212; exec as its <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/01\/report-wework-has-a-new-ceo-and-hes-a-real-estate-not-a-tech-exec\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">new CEO<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, a move that set tongues wagging.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">WeWork then also set a target of becoming <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/finance.yahoo.com\/news\/wework-says-become-free-cash-132630453.html\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">free cash flow positive<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> by a year to 2022 as part of its plan, which was aimed at both boosting valuation and winning back investor trust.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It likely saw the demise of competitor Knotel, which ended up <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/05\/a-look-at-how-proptech-startup-knotel-went-from-a-1-6b-valuation-to-filing-for-bankruptcy\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">filing for bankruptcy <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">and selling assets to an investor, and realized it needed to learn from some of that company\u2019s mistakes.<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Jql6taVlu7\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/08\/wework-is-apparently-doing-better-not-that-softbank-wants-you-to-talk-about-that\/\">WeWork is apparently doing better, not that SoftBank wants you to talk about that<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;WeWork is apparently doing better, not that SoftBank wants you to talk about that&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/08\/wework-is-apparently-doing-better-not-that-softbank-wants-you-to-talk-about-that\/embed\/#?secret=Jql6taVlu7\" data-secret=\"Jql6taVlu7\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The question now is: Has WeWork legitimately turned a corner?\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Since the implementation of its turnaround plan, the company says it has exited out of over 100 pre-open or underperforming locations. (It still has <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.wework.com\/locations\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">over 800 locations<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> globally, according to its website.) WeWork has also narrowed its net loss to $517 million in Q3 2020 from $1.2 billion in the third quarter of 2019.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Meanwhile, revenue has taken a hit, presumably due to the impact of the coronavirus. Revenue slumped to $811 million the 2020 third quarter, compared with $934 million in Q3 2019.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The pandemic presented WeWork with challenges, but also &#8212; some might say &#8212; opportunity.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">With so many people being forced to work from home and avoiding others during the work day, the office space in general struggled. WeWork either had to adapt, or potentially deal with a bigger blow to its valuation and bottom line.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">WeWork\u2019s dilemma is similar to\u00a0 those of real estate companies around the world. With so many companies shifting to remote work not just temporarily, but also permanently, landlords everywhere have had to adjust.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For example, as McKinsey <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.mckinsey.com\/business-functions\/operations\/our-insights\/the-effect-of-government-stimulus-on-commercial-real-estate-amid-covid-19#\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">recently pointed out<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, all landlords have been forced to be more flexible and restructure tenant leases. So in effect, anyone operating commercial real estate space has had to become more flexible, just as WeWork has.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For its part, WeWork has taken a few steps to adapt. For one, it realized its membership-only plan was not going to work anymore, and a dip in membership was evidence of that. So, it worked to open its buildings to more people through new <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.axios.com\/wework-but-make-it-uber-b428fbe2-7fc7-4d4e-aaba-8c8aa2be537d.html\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">On Demand<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/fortune.com\/2020\/10\/24\/wework-coworking-coronavirus-office-commercial-real-estate\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">All Access<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> options. The goal was to give people who were weary of working out of their own homes a place to go, say one day a week, to work. WeWork also saw an opportunity to work with companies to offer up its office space as a perk via an All Access offering, as well as with universities that wanted to give their students an alternative place to study.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For example, <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Georgetown did a pretty unique partnership with WeWork to have one of its locations serve as \u201ctheir replacement library and common space.\u201d And, <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">companies like Brandwatch have recently shifted from leveraging WeWork&#8217;s traditional spaces to instead offer employees access to WeWork locations around the globe via All Access passes.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">WeWork has also launched new product features. At the beginning of the year, the company launched <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">the ability to book space on the weekend and outside of business hours.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"20iYyOqggR\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/01\/report-wework-has-a-new-ceo-and-hes-a-real-estate-not-a-tech-exec\/\">Report: WeWork has a new CEO and he&#8217;s a real estate &#8212; not a tech &#8212; exec<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Report: WeWork has a new CEO and he&#8217;s a real estate &#8212; not a tech &#8212; exec&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/01\/report-wework-has-a-new-ceo-and-hes-a-real-estate-not-a-tech-exec\/embed\/#?secret=20iYyOqggR\" data-secret=\"20iYyOqggR\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>The unbundling of space<\/h2>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">I talked with Prabhdeep Singh, WeWork\u2019s global head of marketplace, who is overseeing the new products and also spearheading WeWork\u2019s shift online, to learn more about the company\u2019s new strategy.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cWhat we\u2019ve essentially done is unbundle our space,\u201d he said. \u201cIt used to be that the only way to enjoy our spaces was via a bundled subscription product and monthly memberships. But we realized with COVID, the world was shifting, and to open up our platform to a broader group of people and make it as flexible as humanly possible. So they can now book a room for a half hour or get a day pass, for example. The use cases are so wide.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Since On Demand launched as a pilot in New York City in August 2020, demand has steadily been climbing, according to Singh. So far, reservations are up by 65% &#8212; and revenue up by 70% &#8212; over the 2020 fourth quarter. But of course, it\u2019s still early and they were starting from a small base. Nearly two-thirds of On Demand reservations are made by repeat customers, he added.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cOver the last year and a half, we\u2019ve been really figuring out what things we want to focus on what things we don\u2019t,\u201d Singh said. \u201cAs a flexible space provider, we are looking at where the world is going. And while we\u2019re a small part of the whole commercial office space industry, we are working to use technology to enable a flexible workspace experience via a great app and the digitization of our spaces.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">For now, things seem to be looking up some. In February, WeWork says it had nearly twice as many active users compared to January. Also, people apparently like having the option to come in at off hours. Weekend bookings now account for an estimated 14.5% of total bookings.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Nearly double as many existing members purchased All Access passes in February 2020 compared to January to complement their existing private office space during COVID, the company said.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In the beginning of the COVID-19, WeWork saw a<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.cnn.com\/2020\/09\/15\/success\/wework-ceo-future-work\/index.html?utm_term=PRV-160019770518545e993ef75ca&amp;utm_source=Work+Transformed+September+15&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=243358_1600197705203&amp;bt_ee_preview=NcSrJnseMIyhSYOHhgpWJBhg8%2Bguk%2FDdFMfL84t5SciDGnr%2BQdbNwGGFmVGUuyiT&amp;bt_ts_preview=1600197705203\"> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">higher departure<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> of small and medium sized businesses (SMBs) than of its enterprise members, partially due to the nature of their businesses and the need to more immediately manage cash flow, the company said. But in the third quarter of 2020, SMB desk sales were up 50% over the second quarter.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Interestingly, throughout the pandemic, WeWork has seen its enterprise segment grow at nearly double the rate of its SMBs, now making up over half of the company\u2019s total membership base.<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"9mL3gI7mQB\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/05\/a-look-at-how-proptech-startup-knotel-went-from-a-1-6b-valuation-to-filing-for-bankruptcy\/\">A look at how proptech startup Knotel went from a $1.6B valuation to filing for bankruptcy<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;A look at how proptech startup Knotel went from a $1.6B valuation to filing for bankruptcy&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/05\/a-look-at-how-proptech-startup-knotel-went-from-a-1-6b-valuation-to-filing-for-bankruptcy\/embed\/#?secret=9mL3gI7mQB\" data-secret=\"9mL3gI7mQB\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">While it\u2019s slowing down investing in new real estate assets in certain markets, it is still working to \u201cright-size\u201d its portfolio via exits.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">And, when it comes to its finances, as of March 2, WeWork said its <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.boerse-berlin.com\/index.php\/Bonds?isin=USU96217AA99\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">bonds<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> were trading at the highest point since the summer of 2019, when the company failed to go public. That\u2019s way up from a 52-week low of about 28%.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cAt ~92% for a ~10% yield, the creditor sentiment is clearly positive and a testament to the overall market&#8217;s belief that WeWork&#8217;s flexible workspace product has a viable future in the future of real estate,\u201d a spokesperson told TechCrunch.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Just last March, WeWork\u2019s <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">bonds<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> were <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">trading at 43 cents on the dollar and S&amp;P Global had lowered WeWork\u2019s credit rating further into junk territory and put the company on watch for further downgrades, reported <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/samanthasharf\/2020\/03\/26\/wework-mounts-charm-offensive-as-bondholders-run-for-the-exits\/?sh=3dcafcfe28dd\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Forbes<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Still, the company is not done adapting. Singh told TechCrunch that to make WeWork\u2019s value proposition even stronger, it\u2019s working to offer a \u201cbusiness in a box.\u201d Late last year, WeWork partnered with a number of companies to offer SMBs and startups, for example, services such as payroll, healthcare and business insurance.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201c<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A lot of people that come to WeWork are growing businesses,\u201d Singh said. \u201cSo while we\u2019ve stuck with our core business services, we\u2019re working to offer more, as in a real suite of HR services that might be complex and expensive for a small business to manage on their own.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It\u2019s also working to be able to offer its On Demand product globally so that people can opt to work out of a WeWork space from any of its locations around the world.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cRight now, we are in the largest work from home experiment,\u201d Singh said. \u201cI think we\u2019re about to shift to the largest return to work experiment ever. We are just going to be very well positioned.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The company appears to be trying to become a more sophisticated real estate company that may not be as flashy as the one of the Adam Neumann era, but more stable and more in demand. But is it trying to do too much, too fast?<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It will be interesting to see how it all goes.<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"a9rJvDqmJ6\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/22\/end-to-end-operators-are-the-next-generation-of-consumer-business\/\">End-to-end operators are the next generation of consumer business<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;End-to-end operators are the next generation of consumer business&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/22\/end-to-end-operators-are-the-next-generation-of-consumer-business\/embed\/#?secret=a9rJvDqmJ6\" data-secret=\"a9rJvDqmJ6\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier \u2018how-to\u2019 event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear first-hand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company-building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in \u2013 there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion. Use code \u201cTCARTICLE at checkout to get <a href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1?promo=tcarticle&amp;display=true\">20 percent off tickets right here<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>For years, there was a debate as to whether WeWork was a tech company or more of a real estate play. At first, most people viewed WeWork as a real estate startup disguised as a tech startup. And as it kept scooping up more and more property, the lines continued to blur. Then we all estate","slug":"real-estate","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/3225"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=3225"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=3225"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=3225"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=3225"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449560034,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/softbank-group\/","name":"SoftBank Group","slug":"softbank-group","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449560034"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449560034"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449560034"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449560034"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449560034"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":115666,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/spokesperson\/","name":"spokesperson","slug":"spokesperson","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/115666"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=115666"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=115666"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=115666"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=115666"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2124924,"date":"2021-03-15T03:04:55","date_gmt":"2021-03-15T10:04:55","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2124924"},"modified":"2021-03-15T04:12:57","modified_gmt":"2021-03-15T11:12:57","slug":"facebook-to-label-all-covid-19-vaccine-posts-with-pointer-to-official-info","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/facebook-to-label-all-covid-19-vaccine-posts-with-pointer-to-official-info\/","title":{"rendered":"Facebook to label all COVID-19 vaccine posts with pointer to official info"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Facebook will soon label all posts discussing the coronavirus vaccination with a pointer to official information about COVID-19, it <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2021\/03\/mark-zuckerberg-announces-facebooks-plans-to-help-get-people-vaccinated-against-covid-19\/\">said today<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>It also revealed it has implemented some new &#8220;temporary&#8221; measures aimed at limiting the spread of vaccine misinformation\/combating vaccine hesitancy &#8212; saying it&#8217;s reducing the distribution of content from users that have violated its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.intern.facebook.com\/help\/230764881494641\">policies on COVID-19 and vaccine misinformation<\/a>; or &#8220;that have repeatedly shared content debunked as False or Altered by our third-party fact-checking partners&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s also reducing distribution of any COVID-19 or vaccine content that fact-checking partners have rated as \u201cMissing Context\u201d, per the blog post.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>While admins for groups with admins or members who have violated its COVID-19 policies will also be required to temporarily approve all posts within their group, it said. (It&#8217;s not clear what happens if a group only has one admin and they have violated its policies.)<\/p>\n<p>Facebook will also &#8220;further elevate information from authoritative sources when people seek information about COVID-19 or vaccines&#8221;, it added.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not clear why users who repeatedly violate Facebook&#8217;s COVID-19 policies do not face at least a period of suspension. (We&#8217;ve asked the company for clarity on its policies.)<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We\u2019re continuing to expand our efforts to address COVID-19 vaccine misinformation by adding labels to Facebook and Instagram posts that discuss the vaccines,&#8221; Facebook said in the <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2021\/03\/mark-zuckerberg-announces-facebooks-plans-to-help-get-people-vaccinated-against-covid-19\/\">Newsroom post<\/a> today.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;These labels contain credible information about the safety of COVID-19 vaccines from the World Health Organization. For example, we\u2019re adding a label on posts that discuss the safety of COVID-19 vaccines that notes COVID-19 vaccines go through tests for safety and effectiveness before they\u2019re approved.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The incoming COVID-19 information labels are rolling out globally in English, Spanish, Indonesian, Portuguese, Arabic and French (with additional languages touted &#8220;in the coming weeks&#8221;), per Facebook.<\/p>\n<p>As well as soon rolling out labels &#8220;on all posts generally about COVID-19 vaccines&#8221; &#8212; pointing users to its COVID-19 Information Center &#8212; Facebook said it would add additional &#8220;targeted&#8221; labels about &#8220;COVID-19 vaccine subtopics&#8221;. So it sounds like it may respond directly to specific anti-vaxxer misinformation it&#8217;s seeing spreading on its platform.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We will also add an additional screen when someone goes to share a post on Facebook and Instagram with an informational COVID-19 vaccine label. It will provide more information so people have the context they need to make informed decisions about what to share,&#8221; Facebook added.<\/p>\n<p>The moves follow revelations that an internal Facebook study of vaccine hesitancy &#8212; which was reported on by the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.washingtonpost.com\/technology\/2021\/03\/14\/facebook-vaccine-hesistancy-qanon\/\">Washington Post<\/a> yesterday after it obtained documents on the large-scale internal research effort &#8212; found a small number of US users are responsible for driving most of the content that&#8217;s hesitant about getting vaccinated.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Just 10 out of the 638 population segments [Facebook&#8217;s study divided US users into] contained 50 percent of all vaccine hesitancy content on the platform,&#8221; the Post reported. &#8220;And in the population segment with the most vaccine hesitancy, just 111 users contributed half of all vaccine hesitant content.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Last week the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.technologyreview.com\/2021\/03\/11\/1020600\/facebook-responsible-ai-misinformation\/\">MIT Technology Review<\/a> also published a deep-dive article probing Facebook&#8217;s approach to interrogating, via an internal &#8216;Responsible AI&#8217; team, the impacts of AI-fuelled content distribution &#8212; which accused the company of prioritizing growth and engagement and neglecting the issue of toxic misinformation (and the individual and societal harms that can flow from algorithmic content choices which amplify lies and hate speech).<\/p>\n<p>In the case of COVID-19, lies being spread about vaccination safety or efficacy present a clear and present danger to public health. And Facebook&#8217;s PR machine does appear to have, tardily, recognized the extent of the reputational risk it&#8217;s facing if it&#8217;s platform is associated with driving vaccine hesitancy.<\/p>\n<p>To wit: Also today it&#8217;s announced the launch of a global COVID-19 education drive that it says it hopes will bring 50M people &#8220;closer to getting vaccinated&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;By working closely with national and global health authorities and using our scale to reach people quickly, we\u2019re doing our part to help people get credible information, get vaccinated and come back together safely,&#8221; Facebook writes in the <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2021\/03\/mark-zuckerberg-announces-facebooks-plans-to-help-get-people-vaccinated-against-covid-19\/\">Newsroom post<\/a> that links directly to a Facebook post by founder Mark Zuckerberg also trailing the new measures, including the launch of a tool that will show U.S. Facebook users where they can get vaccinated and provide them with a link to make an appointment.<\/p>\n<p>Facebook said it plans to expand the tool to other countries as global vaccine availability steps up.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2124926\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2124926\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2124926\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"623\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg 890w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg?resize=150,138 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg?resize=300,275 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg?resize=768,704 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg?resize=680,623 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/NRP-COVID_Vaccine_Product_Bundle_vaccine_finder_tool.jpg?resize=50,46 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2124926\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Facebook&#8217;s vaccine appointment finder tool (Image credits: Facebook)<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Facebook has further announced that the COVID-19 information portal it launched in the Facebook app in March last year which points users to &#8220;the latest information about the virus from local health ministries and the World Health Organization&#8221; is finally being brought to Instagram.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not clear why Facebook hadn&#8217;t already launched the portal on Instagram. But it&#8217;s decided to double down on fighting bad speech (related to vaccines) with better speech &#8212; saying Instagram users will get new stickers they can add to their Instagram Stories &#8220;so people can inspire others to get vaccinated when it becomes available to them&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>In other moves being trailed in Facebook&#8217;s crisis PR blitz today it has touted &#8220;new data and insights&#8221; on vaccine attitudes being made available to public officials via COVID-19 dashboards and maps it was already offering (the data is collected by Facebook&#8217;s Data for Good partners for the effort at Carnegie Mellon University and University of Maryland as part of the <a href=\"https:\/\/dataforgood.fb.com\/tools\/symptomsurvey\/\">COVID-19 Symptom Survey<\/a>).<\/p>\n<p>Albeit, it doesn&#8217;t specify what new information is being added there (or why now).<\/p>\n<p>Also today it said it&#8217;s &#8220;making it easy to track how COVID-19 vaccine information is being spread on social media through <a href=\"https:\/\/apps.crowdtangle.com\/public-hub\/covid19\">CrowdTangle\u2019s COVID-19 Live Displays<\/a>&#8220;.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Publishers, global aid organizations, journalists and others can access real-time, global streams of vaccine-related posts on Facebook, Instagram and Reddit in 34 languages. CrowdTangle also offers Live Displays for 104 countries and all 50 states in the US to help aid organizations and journalists track posts and trends at a regional level as well,&#8221; Facebook added, again without offering any context on why it hadn&#8217;t made it easier to use this tool to track vaccine information spread before.<\/p>\n<p>Its blog post also touts &#8220;new&#8221; partnerships with health authorities and governments on vaccine registration &#8212; while trumpeting the ~3BN messages it says have already been sent &#8220;by governments, nonprofits and international organizations to citizens through official WhatsApp chatbots on COVID-19&#8221;. (As WhatsApp is end-to-end encrypted there is no simple way to quantify how many vaccine misinformation messages have been sent via the same platform.)<\/p>\n<p>Per Facebook, it&#8217;s now &#8220;working directly with health authorities and governments to get people registered for vaccinations&#8221; (such as in the city and province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, which is using WhatsApp as the official channel to send notifications to citizens when it\u2019s their turn to receive the vaccine).<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have partnered with ministries of health and health-focused organizations in more than 170 countries by providing free ads, enabling partners to share their own public health guidance on COVID-19 and information about the COVID-19 vaccine,&#8221; Facebook&#8217;s PR adds in a section of the post which it&#8217;s titled &#8220;amplifying credible health information and resources from experts&#8221;.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"QFxzuKcibV\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/06\/10\/tech-giants-must-open-up-about-the-coronavirus-infodemic-say-eu-lawmakers\/\">Tech giants must open up about the coronavirus &#8216;infodemic&#8217;, say EU lawmakers<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company-building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in \u2013 there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion. distribution of content from users that have violated its Intelligence","slug":"artificial-intelligence-2","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/424613844"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=424613844"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=424613844"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=424613844"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":337,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/health\/","name":"Health","slug":"health","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/337"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=337"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=337"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=337"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":3457,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/social\/","name":"Social","slug":"social","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/3457"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=3457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=3457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=3457"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":576734528,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/coronavirus\/","name":"coronavirus","slug":"coronavirus","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576734528"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576734528"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576734528"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576734528"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576734528"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576740177,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/covid-19\/","name":"COVID-19","slug":"covid-19","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576740177"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576740177"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576740177"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576740177"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576740177"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81819,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/facebook\/","name":"Facebook","slug":"facebook","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81819"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81819"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":42653521,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/instagram\/","name":"Instagram","slug":"instagram","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/42653521"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=42653521"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=42653521"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=42653521"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=42653521"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576599632,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/misinformation\/","name":"misinformation","slug":"misinformation","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576599632"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576599632"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576599632"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576599632"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576599632"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449558131,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/vaccine\/","name":"vaccine","slug":"vaccine","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449558131"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449558131"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449558131"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449558131"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449558131"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":25699058,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/whatsapp\/","name":"WhatsApp","slug":"whatsapp","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/25699058"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=25699058"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=25699058"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=25699058"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=25699058"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2124887,"date":"2021-03-14T14:59:13","date_gmt":"2021-03-14T21:59:13","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2124887"},"modified":"2021-03-15T04:52:16","modified_gmt":"2021-03-15T11:52:16","slug":"stripe-closes-600m-round-at-a-95b-valuation","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/14\/stripe-closes-600m-round-at-a-95b-valuation\/","title":{"rendered":"Stripe closes $600M round at a $95B valuation"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">On the heels of reports that <a href=\"http:\/\/stripe.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Stripe<\/a> was raising yet more money, the payments giant has now confirmed the details. The company has closed in on another $600 million, at a valuation of $95 billion.<\/p>\n<p>Stripe said it will use the funding to expand its business in Europe, with a focus on its European HQ, and also to beef up its global payments and treasury network.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe\u2019re investing a ton more in Europe this year, particularly in Ireland,\u201d said John Collison, President and co-founder of Stripe, in a statement. \u201cWhether in fintech, mobility, retail or SaaS, the growth opportunity for the European digital economy is immense.&#8221;<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Stripe said the financing included backing from two major insurance players. Allianz, via its Allianz X fund, and Axa are in the round, along with Baillie Gifford, Fidelity Management &amp; Research Company, Sequoia Capital, and an investor from the founders&#8217; home country, Ireland\u2019s National Treasury Management Agency (NTMA).<\/p>\n<p>The insurance angle may point to which direction the company is looking to go next. After all, fintech and insurance are closely aligned.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cStripe is an accelerator of global economic growth and a leader in sustainable finance. We are convinced that, despite making great progress over the last 10 years, most of Stripe\u2019s success is yet to come\u201d said Conor O&#8217;Kelly, CEO of NTMA in a statement. \u201cWe\u2019re delighted to back Ireland\u2019s and Europe\u2019s most prominent success story, and, in doing so, to help millions of other ambitious companies become more competitive in the global economy.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The big round, rising valuation, and growing cap table will inevitably lead to questions around where the company is standing with regards to its next steps, and whether that will include a public listing. Stripe has long kept its cards to its chest when it comes to user numbers, revenues, and profit and those details, once again, are not being disclosed with the news today, and nor has it made any comments on IPO plans.<\/p>\n<p>Notably, the confirmation of the news today is at a lower valuation than the valuation Stripe was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/jeffkauflin\/2021\/02\/17\/investors-are-now-valuing-stripe-at-115-billion\/?sh=7721c7554786\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reportedly<\/a> trading at on the secondary market, which was $115 billion; and the round that closed at a $95 billion valuation was also rumored to be coming in at a higher number, over $100 billion.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not clear whether those numbers were never accurate, or if Covid had an impact on pricing, or if European investors simply drove a hard bargain.<\/p>\n<p>The focus on growing in Europe also puts the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/posts\/peter-barron-376b16a_some-personal-news-next-week-ill-be-joining-activity-6770749267343626240-E1K2\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hiring of Peter Barron<\/a> &#8212; the former EMEA VP of communications for Google and a former journalist &#8212; into some context.<\/p>\n<p>Founded in 2010 by John and his brother Patrick Collison (the CEO), Stripe is one of a wave of commerce startups that saw the value of building a simple way for developers to integrate payments into any app or site by way of a few lines of code, at a time when digital and specifically online payments were starting to take off.<\/p>\n<p>Behind that code, the company had done all the hard work of integrating all the different and complex pieces needed to make payments work both in countries and across borders.Over the years, the company has built out a bigger platform around that, a suite of services to position itself as a one-stop shop not just for helping businesses run all of the commercial aspects of their operations, including incorporation, managing fraud, managing cashflow and more.<\/p>\n<p>Within that, Stripe has built out a decent footprint in Europe, with the region accounting for 31 of the 42 countries where it has customers today. While Stripe may have had its start and early traction providing payments infrastructure for startups (and especially small, new startups), today that list includes a lot of big names, too. In Europe, customers include\u00a0Axel Springer, Jaguar Land Rover, Maersk, Metro, Mountain Warehouse and Waitrose, alongside Deliveroo (UK), Doctolib (France), Glofox (Ireland), Klarna (Sweden), ManoMano (France), N26 (Germany), UiPath (Romania) and Vinted (Lithuania).<\/p>\n<p>Even with heavy competition in payments and adjacent services, there is a huge opportunity for more growth. Stripe says that in the wake of Covid and the rise of people shopping considerably more across the web and apps rather than in person, currently some 14% of commerce happens online, a big shift considering that just a year ago it was about 10%.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><em><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/techcrunch-early-stage-is-the-startup-bootcamp-youve-always-needed\/?tpcc=ECTW2020\">Early Stage<\/a> is the premier \u2018how-to\u2019 event for startup entrepreneurs and investors. You\u2019ll hear first-hand how some of the most successful founders and VCs build their businesses, raise money and manage their portfolios. We\u2019ll cover every aspect of company-building: Fundraising, recruiting, sales, product market fit, PR, marketing and brand building. Each session also has audience participation built-in \u2013 there\u2019s ample time included for audience questions and discussion. Use code \u201cTCARTICLE&#8221; at checkout to get <a href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-early-stage-2021-part-1?promo=tcarticle&amp;display=true\">20 percent off tickets right here<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>On the heels of reports that Stripe was raising yet more money, the payments giant has now confirmed the details. The company has closed in on another $600 million, at a valuation of $95 billion. Stripe said it will use the funding to expand its business in Europe, with a focus on its European HQ, [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":13119829,"featured_media":2100354,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"749c0710-1e64-3afd-9c57-73b7f065528d"},"categories":[17396],"tags":[],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/01\/money-explosion-gradient.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3lkegCX","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[13119829],"hide_featured_image":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2124887"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2124887"}],"version-history":[{"count":3,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2124887\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2124978,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2124887\/revisions\/2124978"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/13119829"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2124887&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/13119829"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/2100354"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media?parent=2124887"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":
